description: John Wilson, pictured with wife Hazel, died three days after the fall from his home in Greater Manchester with the blaze sparked by a faulty Beko fridge-freezer, an inquest in Stockport ruled.
title: Faulty Beko fridge-freezer sparked fire that killed man
title_page: Faulty Beko fridge-freezer sparked fire that killed man | Daily Mail Online
text:
A faulty fridge-freezer sparked a house fire that killed a seriously ill lung-transplant patient when he was forced to leap out of an upstairs window to escape the flames, an inquest heard.
John Wilson, 63, died in hospital three days after the blaze, which began due to an electrical problem with the Beko appliance, Stockport Coroner's Court held.
The father broke several bones in his body after the fall, despite landing on a mattress, and also suffered smoke inhalation.
John Wilson, pictured with wife Hazel, died three days after leaping out of an upstairs window at his home to escape a fire, an inquest heard
The blaze which gutted a property in Greater Manchester, pictured, was caused by a faulty fridge-freezer, the inquest heard
Mr Wilson, 63, jumped out of an upstairs window to get out of the property, breaking several bones and suffering smoke inhalation. Mr Wilson, who had recently had a lung transplant, died in hospital three days later
The blaze was made worse after the flames spread to Mr Wilson's oxygen tank, causing it to explode
The property was severely damaged after the fire spread to an oxygen tank Mr Wilson needed following his lung transplant, causing it to explode.
Ten people were hurt in the blaze in August 2016, including his wife Hazel, 53, and some of his neighbours who came to his aid at the property in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester.
According to the Manchester Evening News, his daughter Danielle, 23, 'clung to an upstairs window after the floor fell through', before she managed to pull herself up onto the roof.
She also leapt to the ground and was left with broken ribs and a punctured lung but survived.
Mr Wilson, pictured, also suffered from type 2 diabetes and needed a mobility scooter to move around
It is understood around 500,000 Beko fridge freezers made between 2000 and 2006 have a fault with the defrost timer that can cause a fire.
Miss Wilson and her mother lost everything in the blaze and are still housed in temporary accommodation as they wait for work to begin on rebuilding their home.
Miss Wilson also suffered serious burns and had skin grafts on her feet, which left her unable to walk.
She said: 'My dad would still be here if they had properly recalled all these machines.'
James Bolton, of law firm Leigh Day who represented the Wilson family at the inquest, said: 'This is a harrowing case.
'It is crucial that manufacturers have effective methods for informing customers of safety notices and recalls and that they are persistent in their attempts to make customers aware of any problems.'
A spokesperson for Beko said: 'Our sympathies are with the relatives and friends of Mr Wilson and his family.
'We deeply regret any incident linked to one of our products. Extensive efforts were made to recall the product.
Emergency services rushed to the scene with 10 people hurt, including Mr Wilson's daughter Danielle, 23, who also jumped from the building and suffered a punctured lung
Mr Wilson's family have backed calls for a full product recall while Beko said it had made 'extensive efforts' to tackle a fault with the defrost time that has affected around 500,000 machines made between 2000 and 2006
'We want to reassure our customers that the product involved in this incident has not been produced since late 2006 and none of our current range of appliances are affected.
'We have modified almost 200,000 of the 492,000 relevant products and estimate that, given the age of the products, the majority are now out of the market.'
Visit beko.co.uk/safety or call 0800 917 2018 to check whether you have an affected Beko fridge freezer.
